clinical presentation.reasoning: Clinical presentation refers to the specific observations and symptoms noted in the patient, which are critical for diagnosing the condition. It is a method of gathering patient data to understand the case better.
passages: A 53-year-old woman presented with a recent onset of headaches with aura.
The patient had the typical triad of symptoms

symptom triad analysis.reasoning: Symptom triad analysis involves examining the three distinct groups of symptoms the patient exhibited. This method helps in identifying the nature of the condition and its potential complications.
passages: The patient had the typical triad of symptoms, namely (i) obstructive (light headedness, near syncope, dyspnea, chest pain), (ii) embolic (transient ischemic attacks - TIA, peripheral arterial claudication), and (iii) constitutional (fever, malaise, weight loss).

surgical resection.reasoning: Surgical resection is the method used to remove the myxoma, which was pivotal in resolving the patient's symptoms. It is a specific procedure employed in the treatment of the condition.
passages: the aura and headaches were resolved following resection of the myxoma.
